_prev_prog_3.Description: Sun World International, LLC has prepared a unified Risk & Process Safety Management Program. The program is in compliance with Californias Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program (in California CCR Title 19, Chapter 4.5 Program Level 3 Elements. At the Federal level, Title 40 CFR Part 68), and California OSHAs Process Safety Management (PSM) of Acutely Hazardous Materials standard (in  California CCR Title 8, Section 5189, Process Safety Management of Acutely Hazardous Materials, and Federally Title 29 Code of Federal Regulations (CFR) 1910.119). This program has been prepared to address the risks involved with the presence of anhydrous ammonia in an amount in excess of 10,000 lbs., which is contained in our refrigeration system.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
This program is intended to meet the spirit and intent of the following regulations:



?    California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program - Title 19 CCR, Chapter 4.5

?    Federal EPA Risk Management Program (RMP) - Title 40 CFR ?68

?    California Process Safety Management (PSM) Program, Title 8 CCR ?5189

?    Federal Process Safety Management (PSM) Program, Title 29 CFR ?1910.119



Hereafter this program will be referred to as the RMP-PSM program.



This program is intended to be a "living document". As such, the information, procedures, policies, and documentation that make up this program must be made easily accessible and updated as necessary. To accomplish this, Sun World International has elected to use PSMWriter, software developed and distributed by Resource Compliance, Inc. This software will assist us with updating, maintaining, scheduling, and tracking RMP-PSM related activities. 



1.1    SUN WORLD INTERNATIONAL, RISK & PROCESS SAFETY MANAGEMENT PROGRAM 



This is to inform all interested persons, including employees, that Sun World International has updated/developed their unified RMP-PSM Program. This program has been prepared to address the risks involved in operating and maintaining the following processes which have the presence of hazardous chemicals above threshold quantities: 



Ammonia Refrigeration |    Ammonia    | 41,000 lb



Our RMP-PSM program promotes overall plant, worker, and public safety. The program enables our facility to prevent the occurrence, and minimize the consequences, of significant releases of hazardous chemicals. Overall, the program is designed to prevent accidental fatalities, injuries, and illnesses and avoid physical property damage.



Sun World International has an exemplary safety record, one that we are quite proud of. Our company has many policies and procedures in place to promote overall plant, worker and public safety. We have: 



1.    Prepared a unified program based on the PSM plan to meet CalARP and RMP oblig

ations as well

2.    Organized the program so that it meshes closely with general Sun World International business practices

3.    Utilized PSMWriter software to ensure that all necessary Sun World International employees have access to relevant information (SOPs, PHAs, audits, etc.)



The RMP-PSM program sets forth rules, procedures and practices that will help our employees protect themselves and our neighbors.



1.2    PROCESS DESCRIPTION



Sun World Bakersfield operates a commercial cold storage for grapes in Bakersfield, CA. The facility has an ammonia refrigeration system that provides refrigeration capacity to the following:



(9) Rooms

(4) Precool rooms

(5) Hallways

(2) Loading docks

(2) Liquid recirculators

(1) Palletize room

(1) Hydro-Cooler



The refrigerated spaces are equipped with air-cooling evaporators as required for a pumped overfeed system. The hydrocooler is equipped with four air-cooling evaporators (bare coils) and an accumulator for flooded operation.



All control valve groups are located in the the hallways which require lift-operated equipment for safe access. The refrigeration machinery is contained within two outdoor machinery areas that are surrounded by fencing in order to prevent unauthorized access. There are no vessels, piping or valves located on the roof. A partial list of system components includes:



Outdoor Machinery Area

(4) Screw compressors

(4) Oil separators

(2) High pressure receivers

(1) Liquid transfer vessel

(1) Liquid recirculator

(6) Evaporative condensers



North Recirculator Area

(1) Liquid recirculator

(1) Drop leg vessel

(1) Oil pot



Hydrocooler

(1) Accumulator

(4) Water-cooled evaporators (bare coils)



Front Hallway

(4) Air-cooling evaporators (ceiling-suspended)



Back Hallway

(10) Air-cooling evaporators (ceiling-suspended)



North Hallway

(4) Air-cooling evaporators (ceiling-suspended)



Middle Hallway

(2) Air-cooling evaporators (ceiling-suspended)



South Hallway

(2) Air-cooling

evaporators (ceiling-suspended)



Palletize Room

(1) Air-cooling evaporator (ceiling-suspended)



Room 1

(3) Air-cooling evaporators (ceiling-suspended)



Room 2

(3) Air-cooling evaporators (ceiling-suspended)



Room 3

(3) Air-cooling evaporators (ceiling-suspended)



Room 4

(4) Air-cooling evaporators (ceiling-suspended)



Room 5

(4) Air-cooling evaporators (ceiling-suspended)



Room 6

(3) Air-cooling evaporators (ceiling-suspended)



Room 7

(5) Air-cooling evaporators (ceiling-suspended)



Room 8

(5) Air-cooling evaporators (ceiling-suspended)



Room 9

(5) Air-cooling evaporators (ceiling-suspended)



Precool 1

(4) Air-cooling evaporators (bunker-mounted, plate fin)



Precool 2

(4) Air-cooling evaporators (bunker-mounted, plate fin)



Precool 3 North

(3) Air-cooling evaporators (bunker-mounted, plate fin)



Precool 3 South

(2) Air-cooling evaporators (bunker-mounted, plate fin)



The hallways, precool rooms, storage rooms, and palletize room pumped overfeed system operates as follows:  high pressure liquid from each high pressure receiver is piped through a series of liquid feed solenoid valves, an expansion valve, and into a liquid recirculator.  From there, low pressure liquid is pumped to each evaporator, where it passes through a solenoid valve, hand expansion valve and into evaporator.  Low temperature liquid circulates through the evaporator.  As heat is absorbed, the liquid ammonia vaporizes to form low temperature and pressure gas which passes through an isolation valve and is returned to the liquid recirculator.  The residual liquid is separated from the gas in the recirculator and the gas is piped to the suction inlet on the compressors which elevate the temperature and pressure of the gas.  The high pressure discharge from the compressors is sent to a water cooled evaporative condenser where the high pressure gas ammonia is liquefied and returned to each high pressure receiver.



The hydro-cooler flooded system operates as

follows: high pressure liquid from each high pressure receiver is piped to the hydro-cooler accumulator, where it passes through an expansion valve into an accumulator mounted above the hydro-cooler. From the accumulator, low pressure liquid is circulated through evaporator coils. As heat is absorbed, the liquid ammonia vaporizes to form low temperature and pressure gas which is returned to the accumulator. The suction gas is returned from the accumulator through a suction return line to the south recirculator.  From the south recirculator, ammonia is piped to the suction inlet on the compressors. The high pressure discharge from the compressors is sent to water-cooled evaporative condensers where the high pressure gas ammonia is cooled, liquefied and returned to each high pressure receiver.



The system contains numerous safety devices including sensors which stop the compressors if temperatures or pressures exceed or drop below established limits, and pressure relief valves which vent to the atmosphere if the pressure in the system exceeds their set point. 



There is an ammonia detector installed inside the outdoor machinery area. The sensor is set at the California OSHA permissible exposure limit of 25 ppm, which will activate an audible alarm and strobe. Also, a sampling system is installed in each refrigerated area that provides two-minute interval monitoring. The sampling system is set at the California OSHA permissible exposure limit of 25 ppm, which will activate an audible alarm and strobe.



The ammonia refrigeration system at Sun World Bakersfield consists of vessels, equipment, and valves which are interconnected by piping.  As such, the refrigeration system at Sun World Bakersfield is treated as a single process.



1.3    GENERAL ACCIDENT RELEASE & CHEMICAL SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS



1.3.1    GENERAL 



We inform our employees engaged in process operations of the dangers of an accidental release of anhydrous ammonia in annual safety meetings. During

these meeting we also discuss preventative measures, such as evacuation, in order to be prepared for a release.



Sun World International has also conducted an off-site consequence analysis of worst-case and alternative release scenarios for the ammonia refrigeration process. These are for the purposes of informing the public in the event of an accidental release. The results of the analyses are reported in the body of the program. 



1.3.2    ANHYDROUS AMMONIA



The ammonia refrigeration process at the Sun World International facility is an integral part of the overall business and operates most of the year. The ammonia process contains a total charge of approximately 41,000lbs. It is extremely important that this process is maintained and operated in a safe and efficient manner. Management is committed to making sure that employees are made aware of the potential danger of an ammonia leak.



Our refrigeration personnel monitor the ammonia refrigeration process and keep an active log book of all procedures and transactions that pertain to ammonia. In addition, the process is checked frequently by one of the outside refrigeration contractors that we use. These contractors also assist in performing the annual mechanical integrity inspection of our ammonia equipment. 





1.4    FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



Sun World International has had no accidental release within the last five (5) years.



1.5    EMERGENCY ACTION AND RESPONSE PLAN



Sun World International's emergency action and response program has been developed to satisfy the following requirements:

?    California "Emergency Action Plan" - Title 8 CCR ?3220

?    Federal "Emergency Action Plan" - Title 29 CFR ?1910.38 

?    California "Hazardous Waste Operations and Emergency Response" (HAZWOPER) - Title 8 CCR Title 8 ?5192(q)

?    Federal "Hazardous Waste Operations and Emergency Response" (HAZWOPER) - Title 29 CFR ?1910.120(q)



Strategically, we will respond "minimally" to a release. Under this plan we will call eme

rgency personnel and evacuate the facility. All response activities would be done in coordination with the Local Fire Department and their Hazardous Materials Response Team. 



Every year we review with our employees our evacuation procedures in the event of an emergency, including a hazardous chemical release.



1.6    PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY



Our company has an outstanding safety record, one that we are quite proud of. Many policies and procedures have been implemented to promote overall plant, worker and public safety. Nevertheless, Sun World International continually strives to improve in all areas, including safety.



By utilizing PSMWriter software, all necessary employees have access to every aspect of the RMP-PSM program. This has improved Sun World International's ability to communicate hazardous situations to employees and contractors. In addition, PSMWriter tracks all RMP-PSM related events so that Sun World International's management team can ensure that the RMP-PSM program is being implemented.



Sun World International has implemented all aspects of the RMP-PSM program. When a RMP-PSM program requirement is completed (i.e. mechanical integrity inspection, process hazard analysis, compliance audit, etc.) any specific action items related to that event are entered into PSMWriter, assigned a responsible person, and given a due date. Once the action item has been completed, the resolution can be documented using PSMWriter as well. A list of current or past due action items can be accessed at any time by those with access to PSMWriter.



In addition to utilizing PSMWriter to create, schedule, track, and document events, Sun World International has also entered into a contract with Resource Compliance to obtain help with RMP-PSM program implementation. A copy of Resource Compliance's service agreement has been included in this program with the support material.



For the future, Sun World International now thinks of the RMP-PSM program as a "l

iving document". It is an interactive framework that guides safe action for Sun World International employees, but allows for feedback and continual improvement. Through the RMP-PSM program Sun World International will continue to maintain overall plant worker and public safety.
